page.title: 03A HISTORY OF KINGS NORTON
page.content: The {Romans, Saxons and Normans} left their mark on King's Norton.The Saxons included nortune in the Manor of Bromsgrove. In Norman times it was taken by the King so it was called the King's North town.There is little left of the Norman Church but the present St.Nicolas is over seven hundred years old.In the time of Edward 1 the manor was owned by Roger Mortimer who was hanged by Edward 2 in London. The Saracen's Head was the bailiff's house. King James 1 allowed a market and two {fairs}. In 1629 the Grammar School was opened. During the Civil War there was a skirmish near the village.Later Kings Norton was a {nailmaking centre}. The canal opened in 1799 and the rail- way to Gloucester in 1840.Our primary school was built in 1876.Today it is in a busy suburb of Birmingham.By members of Kings Norton Primary School.
